content: Communists staged a [failed coup attempt](/wiki/1924_Estonian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt "1924 Estonian coup d'état attempt") in [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia").

The drama film *[Romola](/wiki/Romola_(film) "Romola (film)")*, starring [Lillian Gish](/wiki/Lillian_Gish "Lillian Gish"), premiered at [George M. Cohan's Theatre](/wiki/George_M._Cohan%27s_Theatre "George M. Cohan's Theatre") in New York City.
sources: Holston, Kim R. (2013). *Movie Roadshows: A History and Filmography of Reserved-Seat Limited Showings, 1911–1973*. Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company, Inc. p. 38. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-7864-6062-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-6062-5 "Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-6062-5").

content: [Boston Arena](/wiki/Boston_Arena "Boston Arena") hosted the first [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") game ever held on American soil when the [Boston Bruins](/wiki/Boston_Bruins "Boston Bruins") defeated the visiting [Montreal Maroons](/wiki/Montreal_Maroons "Montreal Maroons"), 2 to 1, as both played their first games in franchise history. [Smokey Harris](/wiki/Smokey_Harris "Smokey Harris") scored the first-ever Bruins goal.
sources: ["NHL hockey came to the U.S. on Dec. 1, 1924"](https://www.nhl.com/news/nhl-hockey-came-to-the-u-s-on-dec-1-1924/c-395417). *nhl.com*. National Hockey League. December 1, 2008. Retrieved December 4, 2016. The National Hockey League celebrates another historic anniversary...remembering the first NHL game played in the United States, as the Boston Bruins hosted the Montreal Maroons, both expansion teams, at the Boston Arena on Dec. 1, 1924.
Moore, Mike (December 19, 2010). ["Those Marauding Montreal Maroons"](http://thehockeywriters.com/those-marauding-montreal-maroons/). *The Hockey Writers*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

Pelletier, Joseph (June 2011). ["Joe Pelletier's Greatest Hockey Legends.com - Smokey Harris"](https://web.archive.org/web/20161125050601/http://bruinslegends.blogspot.com/2011/06/smokey-harris.html). *bruinslegends.blogspot.com*. Archived from [the original](http://bruinslegends.blogspot.com/2011/06/smokey-harris.html) on November 25, 2016. Retrieved November 24, 2016. This is Smokey Harris. He is the answer to the trivia question "Who scored the first goal in Boston Bruins history?"...on December 1st, 1924 the Bruins played their first NHL game, hosting their expansion cousins the Montreal Maroons at the Boston Arena. The Maroons opened the scoring that night, with Dinny Dinsmore scoring on an unassisted effort at the 9 minute mark of the 1st period. Cue Harris. At 3:30 of the second period he took a pass from Carson "Shovel Shot" Cooper and beat Maroons goaltender Clint Benedict to open the scoring. Exactly 6 minutes later Cooper scored the only other goal of the night, securing the Bruins a 2-1 victory in their very first game.

content: The musical *[Lady, Be Good](/wiki/Lady,_Be_Good_(musical) "Lady, Be Good (musical)")*, with music by [George](/wiki/George_Gershwin "George Gershwin") and lyrics by [Ira Gershwin](/wiki/Ira_Gershwin "Ira Gershwin"), opened at the [Liberty Theatre](/wiki/Liberty_Theatre "Liberty Theatre") on Broadway.
A devastating [earthquake](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake") struck [Java](/wiki/Java "Java"), killing 727.
sources: ["19241202 Indonesia:Java:Wonosobo"](http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=3256&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display). *[National Geophysical Data Center](/wiki/National_Geophysical_Data_Center "National Geophysical Data Center")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Born:** [Alexander Haig](/wiki/Alexander_Haig "Alexander Haig"), [United States Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States Secretary of State"), in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia") (d. 2010)
**Born:** [Jack Davis](/wiki/Jack_Davis_(cartoonist) "Jack Davis (cartoonist)"), American cartoonist, in [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta") (d. 2016)
**Died:** [Kazimieras Būga](/wiki/Kazimieras_B%C5%ABga "Kazimieras Būga"), 45, Lithuanian linguist

U.S. president [Calvin Coolidge](/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge "Calvin Coolidge") delivered his 2nd [State of the Union](/wiki/State_of_the_Union "State of the Union") message to the [United States Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"). Unlike in 1923, Coolidge delivered a written address instead of giving a speech. The message stated that the present state of the Union "may be regarded with encouragement and satisfaction by every American."
sources: Peters, Gerbhard; Woolley, John T. ["State of the Union Addresses and Messages"](http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/sou.php). *The American Presidency Project*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.
Peters, Gerbhard; Woolley, John T. ["Second Annual Message – December 3, 1924"](http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=29565). *The American Presidency Project*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Born:** [F. Sionil José](/wiki/F._Sionil_Jos%C3%A9 "F. Sionil José"), novelist, in [Rosales](/wiki/Rosales,_Pangasinan "Rosales, Pangasinan"), [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") (d. 2022)
The trial of confessed serial killer [Fritz Haarmann](/wiki/Fritz_Haarmann "Fritz Haarmann") began in Germany.
sources: Parker, R.J. (29 September 2017). *Serial Killers Abridged: : 100 Serial Killers*. Createspace. p. 100. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-4947-7216-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4947-7216-1 "Special:BookSources/978-1-4947-7216-1").

content: **Died:** [Cipriano Castro](/wiki/Cipriano_Castro "Cipriano Castro"), 66, president of Venezuela from 1899 to 1908
[Ibn Saud](/wiki/Ibn_Saud "Ibn Saud") entered [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca "Mecca") in [ihram clothing](/wiki/Ihram_clothing "Ihram clothing") and performed the [umrah](/wiki/Umrah "Umrah").
sources: Vassiliev, Alexei (2012). *King Faisal: Personality, Faith and Times*. London: Saqu Books. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-86356-761-2](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-86356-761-2 "Special:BookSources/978-0-86356-761-2").

content: [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") introduced a bill enforcing widespread press censorship.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. p. 325. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").

content: A first [Woolworths Australia](/wiki/Woolworths_Group_(Australia) "Woolworths Group (Australia)") [department store](/wiki/Department_store "Department store") open in downtown [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), as predecessor name was Woolworths Stupendous Bargain Basement.[*[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*]

France rounded up over 300 communists in raids on their headquarters, including some 70 of foreign nationality that were to be deported. "There are too many foreign communists in France who forget their duty to the country that has given them asylum", Prime Minister [Édouard Herriot](/wiki/%C3%89douard_Herriot "Édouard Herriot") told the [Chamber of Deputies](/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(France) "Chamber of Deputies (France)"). "They are indulging in political demonstrations, and we will not tolerate it, we will not let them meddle in our political life. If we meet with resistance we will break it, and we will deport as many as necessary."
sources: "France Breaks Revolt Plot of Communists". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 7, 1924. pp. 1–2.

content: **Born:** [Wally Cox](/wiki/Wally_Cox "Wally Cox"), comedian and actor, in [Detroit](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit"), [Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") (d. 1973)
**Died:** [Gene Stratton-Porter](/wiki/Gene_Stratton-Porter "Gene Stratton-Porter"), 61, American author, screenwriter and naturalist

The [Social Democratic Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany "Social Democratic Party of Germany") maintained its plurality in the [German federal election](/wiki/German_federal_election,_December_1924 "German federal election, December 1924").

	* [Bent Fabric](/wiki/Bent_Fabric "Bent Fabric") (stage name for Bent Fabricus-Bjerre), pianist and composer, in [Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg "Frederiksberg"), Denmark (d. 2020)

The [Erich von Stroheim](/wiki/Erich_von_Stroheim "Erich von Stroheim")-directed film *[Greed](/wiki/Greed_(1924_film) "Greed (1924 film)")* premiered at the [Cosmopolitan Theatre](/wiki/Majestic_Theatre_(Columbus_Circle) "Majestic Theatre (Columbus Circle)") in New York City.

content: The [NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League")'s [Bruins-Canadiens rivalry](/wiki/Bruins-Canadiens_rivalry "Bruins-Canadiens rivalry") begins at Boston Arena, with a come-from-behind 4-3 win by Montreal over the Bruins.
sources: ["Canadiens Downed Boston, Rallying in Final Period"](https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=Fr8DH2VBP9sC&dat=19241209&printsec=frontpage&hl=en). *The Montreal Gazette*. Boston, MA USA. Canadian Press. December 9, 1924. p. 16. Retrieved June 12, 2017. The world champion Canadiens defeated Boston in a fast game here tonight, 4-3, incidentally giving 5,000 Boston hockey fans the best exhibition of the Canadian game on record here.

content: **Died:** [Xaver Scharwenka](/wiki/Xaver_Scharwenka "Xaver Scharwenka"), 74, German-Polish pianist, composer and teacher

A new session of British parliament was opened by [George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") and [Queen Mary](/wiki/Mary_of_Teck "Mary of Teck"). The [King's speech](/wiki/Speech_from_the_throne "Speech from the throne") included a plan to enlarge the naval base at [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore "Singapore").
sources: Steele, John (December 10, 1924). "Britain to Build Singapore Base, King Announces". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 14.

["The King's Speech"](https://api.parliament.uk/historic-hansard/lords/1924/dec/09/the-kings-speech). *[Parliamentary Debates (Hansard)](/wiki/Hansard "Hansard")*. December 9, 1924. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Born:** [Manlio Sgalambro](/wiki/Manlio_Sgalambro "Manlio Sgalambro"), philosopher and writer, in [Lentini](/wiki/Lentini "Lentini"), Italy (d. 2014)

The 1924 [Nobel Prizes](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") were awarded. The honorees were [Manne Siegbahn](/wiki/Manne_Siegbahn "Manne Siegbahn") of Sweden for [Physics](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics "Nobel Prize in Physics"), [Willem Einthoven](/wiki/Willem_Einthoven "Willem Einthoven") of the Netherlands ([Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine "Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine")), and [Władysław Reymont](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Reymont "Władysław Reymont") of Poland ([Literature](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature")). No Prize was awarded for Chemistry or Peace this year.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. p. 325. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").
["Nobel Prizes 1924"](https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/lists/year/index.html?year=1924&images=yes). *Nobelprize.org*. Nobel Media. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

Photographer [Alfred Stieglitz](/wiki/Alfred_Stieglitz "Alfred Stieglitz") and painter [Georgia O'Keeffe](/wiki/Georgia_O%27Keeffe "Georgia O'Keeffe") were married in [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey").
sources: Reily, Nancy Hopkins (2007). *Georgia O'Keeffe, A Private Friendship, Part I: Walking the Sun Prairie Land*. [Santa Fe, New Mexico](/wiki/Santa_Fe,_New_Mexico "Santa Fe, New Mexico"): Sunstone Press. p. 294. content: **Born:** [Hal Brown](/wiki/Hal_Brown "Hal Brown"), baseball player, in [Greensboro, North Carolina](/wiki/Greensboro,_North_Carolina "Greensboro, North Carolina") (d. 2015)

Addressing American correspondents at the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"), French politician [Aristide Briand](/wiki/Aristide_Briand "Aristide Briand") said that American entry into the League was essential to ensure world peace.
sources: Storer, John (December 13, 1924). "Peace Sure if U.S. Joins World League – Briand". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 5.

content: **Born:** [Ed Koch](/wiki/Ed_Koch "Ed Koch"), mayor of New York City, in [the Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx "The Bronx"), [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") (d. 2013)

Exiled Albanian political figure [Ahmet Zogu](/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania "Zog I of Albania") invaded [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania") with his Yugoslav-backed guerrilla army attempting to overthrow [Fan Noli](/wiki/Fan_S._Noli "Fan S. Noli").
sources: Doody, Richard. ["A chronology of Dictatorial Regimes between the World Wars"](http://worldatwar.net/article/autocracy/). *The World at War*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Born:** [Krishna Prasad Bhattarai](/wiki/Krishna_Prasad_Bhattarai "Krishna Prasad Bhattarai"), political leader, in [Kathmandu](/wiki/Kathmandu "Kathmandu"), [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal") (d. 2011); [Robert Coogan](/wiki/Robert_Coogan "Robert Coogan"), actor, in [Glendale, California](/wiki/Glendale,_California "Glendale, California") (d. 1978)
**Died:** [Samuel Gompers](/wiki/Samuel_Gompers "Samuel Gompers"), 74, American labor leader

The [Henry Kimball Hadley](/wiki/Henry_Kimball_Hadley "Henry Kimball Hadley") dramatic opera *[A Night in Old Paris](/wiki/A_Night_in_Old_Paris "A Night in Old Paris")* premiered at the [Metropolitan Opera](/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera "Metropolitan Opera") House in New York City.

**Born:** [Raj Kapoor](/wiki/Raj_Kapoor "Raj Kapoor"), [Bollywood](/wiki/Bollywood "Bollywood") famous actor, in [Kapoor Haveli](/wiki/Kapoor_Haveli "Kapoor Haveli"), [Peshawar](/wiki/Peshawar "Peshawar") (d. 1988)

In a letter to British Prime Minister [Stanley Baldwin](/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin "Stanley Baldwin"), [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill") opined that [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore "Singapore")'s defences did not need to be completed for another fifteen to twenty years, writing, "I do not believe there is the slightest chance of war with Japan in our lifetime. Japan is at the other end of the world. She cannot menace our vital security in any way."
sources: ["Introduction Lak"](http://www.rhayden.us/defence-expenditure/introduction-lak.html). *Raymond Hayden Economics*. August 4, 2012. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

Green, Joey (2012). *Dumb History: The Stupidest Mistakes Ever Made*. New York: Plume. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-101-58543-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-101-58543-6 "Special:BookSources/978-1-101-58543-6").

content: **Died:** [Friedrich Trendelenburg](/wiki/Friedrich_Trendelenburg "Friedrich Trendelenburg"), 80, German surgeon

The Supreme Court of Hungary confiscated the property of former president [Mihály Károlyi](/wiki/Mih%C3%A1ly_K%C3%A1rolyi "Mihály Károlyi") for high treason. Károlyi was convicted of negotiating with Italy in 1915 to keep the Italians out of the war in exchange for Austrian territory, and for allowing a [communist revolution](/wiki/Hungarian_Soviet_Republic "Hungarian Soviet Republic") to happen in 1919 by deserting his position.
sources: Clayton, John (December 17, 1924). "Hungary Seizes Big Estates of Count Karolyi". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 3.

content: **Born:** [Loudon Wainwright, Jr.](/wiki/Loudon_Wainwright,_Jr. "Loudon Wainwright, Jr."), American writer (d. 1988)

Seven of the eight teams in baseball's [American League](/wiki/American_League "American League") presented a resolution to commissioner [Kenesaw Mountain Landis](/wiki/Kenesaw_Mountain_Landis "Kenesaw Mountain Landis") saying that the "misconduct" of League president [Ban Johnson](/wiki/Ban_Johnson "Ban Johnson") would cease, "or his immediate removal from office will follow." The resolution also declared "that legislation will be adopted that will limit his activities to the internal affairs of the American league." [Phil Ball](/wiki/Phil_Ball_(baseball) "Phil Ball (baseball)") of the [St. Louis Browns](/wiki/History_of_the_St._Louis_Browns "History of the St. Louis Browns") was the only team owner who did not sign the resolution.
sources: Crusinberry, James (December 18, 1924). "Landis Wins; Remains Czar of Baseball". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1 and 19.

content: The football club [Associação Atlética Portuguesa (RJ)](/wiki/Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Atl%C3%A9tica_Portuguesa_(RJ) "Associação Atlética Portuguesa (RJ)") was founded in Brazil.
**Born:** [Margaret Wigiser](/wiki/Margaret_Wigiser "Margaret Wigiser"), baseball player, in [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn"), [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") (d. 2019)

[Pope Pius XI](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI "Pope Pius XI") made his first statement against communism after an abandoned pontifical relief mission returned from Russia. He said the Vatican would continue to make efforts to help needy Russians, but "nobody certainly can have thought by our efforts on behalf of the Russian people we intended in any way to lend our support to a system of government which we are so far from approving."
sources: "Pope in Bitter Denouncement of Communism". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 19, 1924. p. 5.

content: German serial killer [Fritz Haarmann](/wiki/Fritz_Haarmann "Fritz Haarmann") was sentenced to death for murdering twenty-four young men.
**Born:** [Doug Harvey](/wiki/Doug_Harvey_(ice_hockey) "Doug Harvey (ice hockey)"), hockey player, in [Montreal, Quebec](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal"), Canada (d. 1989)
**Born:** [Cicely Tyson](/wiki/Cicely_Tyson "Cicely Tyson"), Tony and Emmy Award-winning actor and model, in [Harlem, New York City, New York](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem"), U.S.A (d. 2021)

[Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") was released from [Landsberg Prison](/wiki/Landsberg_Prison "Landsberg Prison") as part of a general amnesty for political prisoners. He returned to his small [Munich apartment](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler%27s_Munich_apartment "Adolf Hitler's Munich apartment") where his friends threw him a party.
sources: Donnelley, Paul (2012). *Assassination!*. Dataday Publishing. p. 55. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-908963-02-4](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-908963-02-4 "Special:BookSources/978-1-908963-02-4").

Zalampas, Sherree Owens (1990). *Adolf Hitler: A Psychological Interpretation of His Views on Architecture, Art and Music*. Bowling Green State University Popular Press. p. 51. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-87972-488-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87972-488-7 "Special:BookSources/978-0-87972-488-7").

content: [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") presented legislation repealing the much-criticized [Acerbo Law](/wiki/Acerbo_Law "Acerbo Law").
sources: "Mussolini Pulls Surprise; Wants Early Election". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 21, 1924. p. 14.

content: 100 were wounded in rioting between communists and police in Berlin. About 50,000 communists turned into a crushing mob when they gathered to greet [Erich Mühsam](/wiki/Erich_M%C3%BChsam "Erich Mühsam") upon his release from prison in the same general amnesty that freed [Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler").
sources: [Schultz, Sigrid](/wiki/Sigrid_Schultz "Sigrid Schultz") (December 22, 1924). "Reds in Berlin Greet 'Martyr'; 100 Wounded". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 5.

content: **Born:** [Dankwart Rustow](/wiki/Dankwart_Rustow "Dankwart Rustow"), professor of political science and sociology, in Berlin (d. 1996)

An [interallied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") military committee headed by [Ferdinand Foch](/wiki/Ferdinand_Foch "Ferdinand Foch") decided that troops would not withdraw from the [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne") area on January 10, 1925, as specified in the [Treaty of Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles"), because Germany had not fulfilled its disarmament provisions. Angry articles in the German press accused the Allies of breaking the [Dawes Pact](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan").
sources: Wales, Henry (December 23, 1924). "'Stay on Rhine,' Foch Order". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: The [F. W. Murnau](/wiki/F._W._Murnau "F. W. Murnau")-directed film *[The Last Laugh](/wiki/The_Last_Laugh_(1924_film) "The Last Laugh (1924 film)")* premiered at the [Ufa-Palast am Zoo](/wiki/Ufa-Palast_am_Zoo "Ufa-Palast am Zoo") in Berlin.

The [Nicolae Bretan](/wiki/Nicolae_Bretan "Nicolae Bretan") opera *[Golem](/wiki/Golem_(Bretan_opera) "Golem (Bretan opera)")* was first performed at the [Hungarian Theater](/wiki/Hungarian_Theatre_of_Cluj "Hungarian Theatre of Cluj") in [Cluj](/wiki/Cluj-Napoca "Cluj-Napoca"), [Romania](/wiki/Romania "Romania").
sources: Gagelmann, Hartmut (2000). *Nicolae Bretan, His Life, His Music, Volume 1*. Pendragon Press. p. 48. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [1-57647-021-0](/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-57647-021-0 "Special:BookSources/1-57647-021-0").

content: German president [Friedrich Ebert](/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert "Friedrich Ebert") lost a libel trial in [Magdeburg](/wiki/Magdeburg "Magdeburg"). Newspaper editor Erwin Rothart was sentenced to three months in prison for insulting the president, but his accusation that Ebert had betrayed the country for leading a strike in 1918 was ruled as proven.
sources: ["23.12.1924: Ebert Loses Libel Trial"](http://www.todayinhistory.de/index.php?what=thmanu&lang=en&manu_id=1683&tag=23&monat=12&weekd=&year=2014&weekdnum=&dayisset=1&lang=en). *[Deutsche Welle](/wiki/Deutsche_Welle "Deutsche Welle")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: [Albanian](/wiki/Albania "Albania") Prime Minister [Fan Noli](/wiki/Fan_S._Noli "Fan S. Noli") and his ministers fled [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana") as rebel forces led by the deposed leader [Ahmet Zogu](/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania "Zog I of Albania") approached the city.
sources: Clayton, John (December 24, 1924). "Albanian Hangs for U.S. Deaths; Caused Revolts (Bulletin)". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 3.

content: **Born:** [Bob Kurland](/wiki/Bob_Kurland "Bob Kurland"), basketball player, in [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri") (d. 2013)

[Pope Pius XI](/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI "Pope Pius XI") opened the [holy door](/wiki/Holy_door "Holy door") at [St. Peter's Basilica](/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica "St. Peter's Basilica") to begin the [Jubilee Year](/wiki/Jubilee_(Christianity) "Jubilee (Christianity)") of 1925.
sources: "Pope Pius Opens Holy Door at Celebration of 23d Jubilee Year". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 25, 1924. p. 25.

content: [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania") was declared a republic as [Ahmet Zogu](/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania "Zog I of Albania") entered [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana") without resistance, reclaiming leadership of the country and completing the overthrow of [Fan Noli](/wiki/Fan_S._Noli "Fan S. Noli")'s government.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. p. 325. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").
Clayton, John (December 25, 1924). "Albanian Rebel Army in Tirana; Civil War Ends". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: Eight people died in an [Imperial Airways de Havilland DH.34 crash](/wiki/1924_Imperial_Airways_de_Havilland_DH.34_crash "1924 Imperial Airways de Havilland DH.34 crash"), seconds after taking off from [Croydon Airport](/wiki/Croydon_Airport "Croydon Airport"). It was Britain's worst air disaster to date.

The [Babbs Switch fire](/wiki/Babbs_Switch_fire "Babbs Switch fire") killed thirty-six people in a one-room school house at [Babbs Switch, Oklahoma](/wiki/Babbs_Switch,_Oklahoma "Babbs Switch, Oklahoma").

**Born:** [Mohammed Rafi](/wiki/Mohammed_Rafi "Mohammed Rafi"), playback singer, in [Kotla Sultan Singh](/wiki/Kotla_Sultan_Singh "Kotla Sultan Singh"), [British India](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") (d. 1980)

**Died:** [David Stewart](/wiki/David_Stewart_(RAF_officer) "David Stewart (RAF officer)"), 34, British flying ace (pilot in the fatal [Imperial Airways de Havilland DH.34 crash](/wiki/1924_Imperial_Airways_de_Havilland_DH.34_crash "1924 Imperial Airways de Havilland DH.34 crash"))

A post-season [college football](/wiki/College_football "College football") [bowl game](/wiki/Bowl_game "Bowl game") known as the [Los Angeles Christmas Festival](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Christmas_Festival "Los Angeles Christmas Festival") was played in the [Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Memorial_Coliseum "Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum"). The [USC Trojans](/wiki/USC_Trojans_football_under_Gus_Henderson#1924 "USC Trojans football under Gus Henderson") defeated the [Missouri Tigers](/wiki/Missouri_Tigers_football "Missouri Tigers football"), 20–7.
The [Broadway Theatre](/wiki/Broadway_Theatre_(53rd_Street) "Broadway Theatre (53rd Street)") opened in midtown-[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"), New York City.

**Born:**
	* [Moktar Ould Daddah](/wiki/Moktar_Ould_Daddah "Moktar Ould Daddah"), the first [president of Mauritania](/wiki/President_of_Mauritania "President of Mauritania") (from 1960 to 1978); in [Boutilimit](/wiki/Boutilimit "Boutilimit"), [French West Africa](/wiki/French_West_Africa "French West Africa") (d. 2003)
	* [Rod Serling](/wiki/Rod_Serling "Rod Serling"), screenwriter, playwright, television producer and narrator known for [*The Twilight Zone*](/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone_(1959_TV_series) "The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)"); in [Syracuse, New York](/wiki/Syracuse,_New_York "Syracuse, New York") (d. 1975)
	* [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee"), 11th prime minister of India from 1998 to 1999; in [Gwalior](/wiki/Gwalior "Gwalior"), [Gwalior State](/wiki/Gwalior_State "Gwalior State"), [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") (d. 2018)

[Moktar Ould Daddah](/wiki/Moktar_Ould_Daddah "Moktar Ould Daddah"), the first [president of Mauritania](/wiki/President_of_Mauritania "President of Mauritania") (from 1960 to 1978); in [Boutilimit](/wiki/Boutilimit "Boutilimit"), [French West Africa](/wiki/French_West_Africa "French West Africa") (d. 2003)

[Rod Serling](/wiki/Rod_Serling "Rod Serling"), screenwriter, playwright, television producer and narrator known for [*The Twilight Zone*](/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone_(1959_TV_series) "The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)"); in [Syracuse, New York](/wiki/Syracuse,_New_York "Syracuse, New York") (d. 1975)

[Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee"), 11th prime minister of India from 1998 to 1999; in [Gwalior](/wiki/Gwalior "Gwalior"), [Gwalior State](/wiki/Gwalior_State "Gwalior State"), [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") (d. 2018)
Soviet ambassador [Leonid Krassin](/wiki/Leonid_Krassin "Leonid Krassin") said that Russia would not pay any outstanding debts accrued in the days of the Tsar.
sources: "Russia Will Not Pay Czar Debts, Krassin States". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 27, 1924. p. 1.

content: [Judy Garland](/wiki/Judy_Garland "Judy Garland") made her show business debut at the age of .mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);clip-path:polygon(0px 0px,0px 0px,0px 0px);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}2+1⁄2, singing "[Jingle Bells](/wiki/Jingle_Bells "Jingle Bells")" at her parents' theater in [Grand Rapids, Minnesota](/wiki/Grand_Rapids,_Minnesota "Grand Rapids, Minnesota").
sources: ["Judy Garland Nutshell Biography"](http://www.jgdb.com/bio.htm). *Judy Garland Database*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: **Died:** [William Emerson](/wiki/William_Emerson_(British_architect) "William Emerson (British architect)"), 81, British architect

An editorial written by the estranged Fascist politician [Cesare Rossi](/wiki/Cesare_Rossi_(politician) "Cesare Rossi (politician)") ran in [Giovanni Amendola](/wiki/Giovanni_Amendola "Giovanni Amendola")'s newspaper *[Il Mondo](/wiki/Il_Mondo_(newspaper) "Il Mondo (newspaper)")*, simultaneously published in other opposition papers. In it, Rossi claimed that [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") had directly ordered the Fascists to carry out several crimes.
sources: Sarfatti, Margherita (2014). Sullivan, Brian R. (ed.). *My Fault: Mussolini As I Knew Him*. New York: Enigma Books. pp. 112–113. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-936274-40-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6 "Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6").
Storer, John (December 28, 1924). "Italian Premier is Accused of Fascist Crimes". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 12.

content: During a transfer of 10.5 tonnes [dynamite](/wiki/Dynamite "Dynamite") from a [cargo ship](/wiki/Cargo "Cargo") to [freight car](/wiki/Freight_car "Freight car"), there was an explosion in Temiya railway station, [Otaru](/wiki/Otaru "Otaru"), [Hokkaido](/wiki/Hokkaido "Hokkaido"), Japan, 94 persons were killed and more than 300 persons were hurt, according to a Japanese government official document figured report.

A [general election](/wiki/Honduran_general_election,_1924 "Honduran general election, 1924") was conducted in [Honduras](/wiki/Honduras "Honduras"). [Miguel Paz Barahona](/wiki/Miguel_Paz_Barahona "Miguel Paz Barahona") of the conservative [National Party](/wiki/National_Party_of_Honduras "National Party of Honduras") was elected president virtually unopposed, as liberals boycotted the election.
sources: Leonard, Thomas M. (2011). *The History of Honduras*. Santa Barbara, California: Greenwood. p. 100. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-313-36304-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-36304-7 "Special:BookSources/978-0-313-36304-7").

content: With Franco-German tensions high over the issue of the occupation of [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), a sensational report was published in Paris claiming that German scientists had secretly developed a new and devastating poison gas that could annihilate a whole city in a matter of hours.
sources: "French claim Germans Make New Deadly Gas". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 29, 1924. p. 4.

content: The [Herbert Brenon](/wiki/Herbert_Brenon "Herbert Brenon")-directed adventure film *[Peter Pan](/wiki/Peter_Pan_(1924_film) "Peter Pan (1924 film)")*, starring [Betty Bronson](/wiki/Betty_Bronson "Betty Bronson") in the title role, was released.
[Kid McCoy](/wiki/Kid_McCoy "Kid McCoy") was found guilty of manslaughter in the August 12 death of his live-in mistress.
sources: "Kid McCoy Found Guilty: Manslaughter". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 30, 1924. p. 1.

content: **Died:** [Carl Spitteler](/wiki/Carl_Spitteler "Carl Spitteler"), 79, Swiss writer and [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature") laureate

[Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito Mussolini") called an unexpected cabinet meeting and requested a show of support from all present, which he received from a majority. The two Liberal ministers in Mussolini's cabinet were convinced to withdraw their resignations.
sources: Sarfatti, Margherita (2014). Sullivan, Brian R. (ed.). *My Fault: Mussolini As I Knew Him*. New York: Enigma Books. pp. 112–113. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-936274-40-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6 "Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6").
"Mussolini Leaps Fresh Obstacle; Saves Cabinet". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. December 31, 1924. p. 7.

content: German Foreign Minister [Gustav Stresemann](/wiki/Gustav_Stresemann "Gustav Stresemann") told international media that peace in Europe and fulfillment of the [Dawes Plan](/wiki/Dawes_Plan "Dawes Plan") were in danger unless a compromise was reached on the [Cologne](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne") evacuation issue.
sources: [Seldes, George](/wiki/George_Seldes "George Seldes") (December 31, 1924). "Order of Allies Brews New Hate Crop in Europe". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 7.

content: Thirty-three [Blackshirt](/wiki/Milizia_Volontaria_per_la_Sicurezza_Nazionale "Milizia Volontaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale") consuls arrived unannounced in Mussolini's office, demanding that Mussolini crush the opposition or they would do so without him.
sources: Sarfatti, Margherita (2014). Sullivan, Brian R. (ed.). *My Fault: Mussolini As I Knew Him*. New York: Enigma Books. pp. 112–113. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-936274-40-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6 "Special:BookSources/978-1-936274-40-6").

content: Italian police were ordered to search the houses of prominent opposition leaders over allegations that enemies of the government had stockpiled vast stores of arms. Issues of opposition newspapers in several Italian cities were seized, with [Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence") becoming especially violent as thousands of Blackshirts converged on the city and ransacked several buildings, including the printing plant of an opposition newspaper which was set on fire.
sources: "Thumbscrews Turned on Foes by Mussolini". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. January 1, 1925. p. 1.

content: Three of four brothers in the Barmat family of merchants were arrested as the industrial corruption scandal known as the [Barmat scandal](/wiki/Barmat_scandal "Barmat scandal") broke in Germany. One report claimed that President [Friedrich Ebert](/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert "Friedrich Ebert")'s son ["Fritz"](/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert,_Jr. "Friedrich Ebert, Jr.") was connected to the scandal.
sources: Fulda, Bernhard (2009). *Press and Politics in the Weimar Republic*. Oxford University Press. pp. 94–96. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-19-954778-4](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954778-4 "Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954778-4").

[Seldes, George](/wiki/George_Seldes "George Seldes") (January 1, 1925). "Berlin Bankers Held in Swindle of $10,000". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 19.

content: **Born:** [Frank J. Kelley](/wiki/Frank_J._Kelley "Frank J. Kelley"), 50th [Michigan Attorney General](/wiki/Michigan_Attorney_General "Michigan Attorney General"), in [Detroit](/wiki/Detroit "Detroit"), [Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") (d. 2021); [Taylor Mead](/wiki/Taylor_Mead "Taylor Mead"), writer, actor and performer, in [Grosse Point, Michigan](/wiki/Grosse_Point,_Michigan "Grosse Point, Michigan") (d. 2013)
**Died:** [Sir Samuel William Knaggs](/wiki/Samuel_William_Knaggs "Samuel William Knaggs"), 68, British civil servant
